problem.markdown:
>>Which of the following are part of Goldratt's general principles and observations? <<
[x] If you produce what you can't sell, you get inventory [ ] People tend to excel under stress and efficiency will increase. [ ] It's mostly likely the Plant Manager's fault, since he is steering the ship. [x] Balance (keeping everything busy) is not a good strategy because inventory goes up. [ ] Data in factories is great. [x] Conventional accounting methods are misleading. [x] It is not useful to discuss value or value added.
[Explanation] Here are the general principles we believe Goldratt outlined in his book. 1. Nobody is at fault. The system is at fault. 2. Under stress, efficiency declines, and people do foolish things. 3. If you produce what you can't sell, you get inventory (WIP or FG). 4. Balance (keeping everything busy) is not a good strategy because inventory goes up. 5. It is not useful to discuss value or value added. 6. Data in factories is lousy. 7. Conventional accounting methods are misleading. 8. It is important to -communicate with and convince everybody about important changes. -get everybody's good ideas -remember reasons for policies and procedures { in order, for example, to get rid of unnecessary heat-treats which were required to make non-bottleneck operations faster. -learn things for yourself rather than having them told to you 9. Idle time is not bad (other than at the bottleneck). It is inevitable. 10. Time a part spends in a in plant = -setup time (part waits while resource is set up) - + process time - + queue time (part waits while resource is working on something else) - + wait time (part waits for another part for assembly) 11. Most time is spent in queue + wait. -For parts going through bottleneck, queue time is dominant. -For others, wait time is dominant. 12. An hour lost at a bottleneck is lost forever. An hour saved at a non-bottleneck is a mirage. [Explanation]

div.p: Explanation
Here are the general principles we believe Goldratt outlined in his book.
1. Nobody is at fault. The system is at fault.
2. Under stress, efficiency declines, and people do foolish things.
3. If you produce what you can't sell, you get inventory (WIP or FG).
4. Balance (keeping everything busy) is not a good strategy because inventory goes up.
5. It is not useful to discuss value or value added.
6. Data in factories is lousy.
7. Conventional accounting methods are misleading.
8. It is important to
-communicate with and convince everybody about important changes.
-get everybody's good ideas
-remember reasons for policies and procedures { in order, for example, to get rid of unnecessary heat-treats which were required to make non-bottleneck operations faster.
-learn things for yourself rather than having them told to you
9. Idle time is not bad (other than at the bottleneck). It is inevitable.
10. Time a part spends in a in plant =
-setup time (part waits while resource is set up)
- + process time
- + queue time (part waits while resource is working on something else)
- + wait time (part waits for another part for assembly)
11. Most time is spent in queue + wait.
-For parts going through bottleneck, queue time is dominant.
-For others, wait time is dominant.
12. An hour lost at a bottleneck is lost forever. An hour saved at a non-bottleneck is a mirage.
